The Boardinghouse, San Francisco, California 
Genre Comedy 
Length 38:10 
Label Warner Bros. Records 
Producer William E. McEuen 
 

Let?s Get Small (1977) was Steve Martin&#039;s first album, and a major success. It included Excuse Me, a comedy bit whose title went on to become a national catch phrase. The album went platinum and peaked at #10 on the Billboard Pop Albums Chart, which is traditionally dominated by music.

This album won the Grammy Award in 1978 for Best Comedy Album.

An excerpt from the title cut:

"I&#039;m on drugs. I&#039;m, uh, I mean, you know what it is. What&#039;s the deal, man? I like to get small. It&#039;s a wild, wild drug. Very dangerous for kids though, because they get really small. I know I shouldn&#039;t get small when I&#039;m drivin&#039;, but, uh, I was drivin&#039; around the other day, you know *whistles tunefully* and a cop pulls me over. And he goes, ?Hey, are you small?? I said, ?No, I&#039;m tall, I&#039;m tall.? He said, &#039;Well, I&#039;m gonna have to measure you.&#039; They&#039;ve got a little test they give you; it&#039;s a balloon, and if you can get inside of it, they know... you&#039;re small. And they can&#039;t put you in a regular cell either, because you walk right out."

Steve Martin is my favourite comedian, and even if you&#039;re put off by the likes of Cheaper By the Dozen or the new Pink Panther films, (the latter I actually didn&#039;t mind) don&#039;t worry ! His stand-up is nothing like that.

His stand-up career was short and sweet and shows a different side to Steve&#039;s comedy; I&#039;d say his career as a stand-up comic is very different from his movies in the 80s and certainly his movies today.

In his act, in a sense he plays a much more arrogant and stupid version of himself, in the style Larry David uses in Curb Your Enthusiasm. Lines like &#039;I know what you&#039;re saying; Steve, how can you be so fucking funny?&#039; are hilarious when he says it like he actually means it. His act is interspersed with banjo playing and surreal anecdotes; one of his main objectives in stand-up was to make the audience laugh without including punchlines in his jokes.


Enjoy !


You&#039;ll like this if you like Steven Wright, Rodney Dangerfield, Jerry Seinfeld, Larry David.


Also if you do like this, go and buy Steve Martin&#039;s &#039;Born Standing Up&#039;, his autobiography charting his rise to fame and why he left stand-up for film, it&#039;s a great book.




Jimmy.
